Yup. Start by axing any program that has any of these words: awareness, diversity, inclusiveness, equity, fairness, opportunity, liaison, community, urinalysis.
Start with every rate holding up our security forces. MA's are critically understaffed and other rates spend ridiculous amounts of time away from their own jobs to do securities.

Admiral, end the SAPR and GMT and Diversity directorates.  Have the the strength to end these non warfighting devisive and cancerous programs.   Take a fleet survey and forcibly retire or separate anyone not capable of fighting.   We need Warriors. Not social justice warriors.  We will support you. What we need are good Sailors that are great at their job and great at their collateral duty. It has to be balanced. There are too many Navy programs that require devoted time to upkeep requirements. Sailors who "only" do there job are not much better than those that "only" do collateral duties! That just leaves more collateral duties that must be taken care of by less people.

Finally!  Someone gets it!  One of the reasons I got out was because I was sick of seeing guys that filled up their time with collaterals so they didn't have to do their job get the EP and the guys that did their jobs were treated like garbage because they did their job but didn't have any collaterals. My Mischa tries to open our doors when she wants them open like Simon's Cat did here.  mischa knows enough to jump up and grab the door knob, but she doesn't know how to get the door itself to swing open.  So when I hear a "Rattle.  Rattle. Plop.", I know she's failed at getting the door to swing open.  Until she learns to pull back with her weight, she'll have to rely on me to open the door for her.   :)
Definition of a door: something a cat is perpetually on the wrong side of.
And when you do finally open the door for a cat, they don't rush in, they sit and think about it for a little while.  Simon really captured that behavior.

A better ending would have been for Simon's cat to have looked in, and then strolled casually off out again... that's what our cats tend to do... or, if in the kitchen with two doors into our conservatory, one open, one closed, they will often demand to be allowed out, or in, through the closed one...
